author: Elizabeth Leader Smith
title: Austin's Top Upcoming Food Events

organizations.name: greater austin black chamber of commerce

text:
Sunday, January 22 Afternoon Tea at Brentwood Social House What: It's finally high tea time for this Central Austin newcomer. Make plans to join in for its first afternoon tea featuring: coronation chicken naan, smoked salmon, and cucumber and cream cheese sandwiches; scones with clotted cream and raspberry jam; vanilla custard, cherry pie and a chocolate truffle; and unlimited pots of tea. Where: Brentwood Social House, Brentwood Details : 4 to 6 p.m. $34. Reservations required by January 17. Call or stop by to reserve a spot. 
Out of the Cellar: A Rare Texas Beer Dinner What: Farm to fork eatery Greenhouse Craft Food is hosting a five-course beer pairing dinner featuring five rare kegs of Texas craft brews only be available at this dinner. The featured breweries include Saint Arnold Brewing Company, Red Horn Coffee House and Brewing Co., (512) Brewing Company, Independence Brewing Co. and Rahr & Sons Brewing Company. The menu features duck rillettes toast, boar carnitas tacos, foie gras-seared halibut, and more. Where: Greenhouse Craft Food, East Old Settlers Boulevard, Round Rock Details: 6:30 p.m. (passed appetizers), 7 p.m. (dinner). $100 including tax and tip. Tickets here . Monday, January 23 Olive & June's Amari Dinner What : For their first event of 2017, Olive & June will host an Amari dinner highlighting the versatility and flavors of the Southern Italian cuisine. Executive Chef Brian Moses and Beverage Director Paul Ozbirn have worked together to create a four-course menu with craft cocktail pairings for each course. Where : Olive & June, Central Austin Details : Dinner starts at 6:30 p.m. Tickets are $68 and can be found here , along with the complete menu. Tuesday, January 24 Old World vs. New World Wine TastingWhat : Mingle with fellow wine lovers while enjoying six different wine tastings paired with small bites from executive chef, Jacob Weaver. Master Sommelier, Guy Stout, will be on-hand to guide you through the tasting. Where : Juliet Ristorante, Barton Springs Road Details: 5 to 6:30 p.m. $25 includes six wine tastings and small bites. Tickets here . Hot Takes! A Debate About Food What : Hot Takes is Austin’s debate night, where amateurs, experts, and comedians come together to argue about absurd topics some of them care deeply about. This week's topic — Food: Should We Eat It? Where: The Townsend, Congress Avenue Details: 7:30 to 10 p.m. Free but RSVP encouraged. Alcomar's Chef Dinner In Good Company with Heritage SeafoodWhat: Join Alcomar for its dinner series featuring local vendors favorited by chef Alma Alcocer and chef Jeff Martinez. January's four-course dinner highlights fresh catches from local fishmonger Ben McBride's company, Heritage Seafood, paired with tequila cocktails from Azuñia Tequila. McBride launched Heritage Seafood with the intention of offering chefs a "dock to dock" experience. The menu features pickled shrimp tostaditas, flounder tiradito, ember fire-roasted grouper, grilled pineapple upside down cake, and more. Details : 8 p.m. $65. Tickets here. Thursday, January 26 
Pinot in the City Austin What: More than 65 Oregon wineries, represented by the owners or vintners themselves, will descend upon Austin to showcase world-class Willamette Valley wines. A portion of proceeds benefits the Austin Food & Wine Alliance. Where: JW Marriott, 110 East Second Street Details: Noon to 3:30 p.m. Trade Tasting. Advance registration required here. 5 p.m. VIP Consumer Tasting. $125. 6 p.m. General Admission Consumer Tasting $75. Tickets here . Saturday, January 28 The Chix Brunch What : The Chix of Texas Keeper Cider + SPUN Ice Cream + Anjore are back for for the third installment of "Chix Dinner Series," though this time it’s brunch (or brinner) featuring a menu of fried chicken in a waffle cone, French toast, veg eggs, and creamsicle cider-mosa and plenty of Texas Keeper Cider on tap. They will be playing songs by famous female expats and immigrants in the U.S. Where : Texas Keeper Cider, Manchaca Details : noon to 3 p.m. Register here. $3 donation (or more if you can). Donations will benefit GirlForward Austin . All genders, ages, and dogs on leashes welcome. Austin Bacon and Beer Festival What: Edible Austin and Eat Boston are teaming up for their fourth annual Austin Bacon and Beer Festival . The day event will showcase bacon-centric food prepared by bacon-loving Austin and Central Texas chefs, paired with craft brews. A portion of the proceeds will benefit the Central Texas Food Bank. Where: Brazos Hall, 204 East 4th StreetDetails: 1 to 4 p.m. Both the $47 general admission and $100 defend bacon tickets can be purchased here . Sunday, January 29 Somms Under Fire Competition What : Sommeliers Eric S. Crane with Empire Distributors, Hai Tran with The Rittenhouse Hotel, and Jill Zimorski (who was recently recognized by Wine Enthusiast Magazine as one of the "Top 40 under 40 taste makers 2016") will compete against each other in a fast paced evening of bites and sips. The winner will leave with a week-long internship in Burgundy and $2K travel grant. Attendees can expect to sample many different pairings and have the chance to vote for their favorite sommelier—the winner will receive an educational trip to Austria. Where : The AT&T Executive Education & Conference Center, Downtown Details : 6 to 11:30 p.m. Both the $65 general admission and $130 VIP tickets can be purchased here . Tuesday, January 31 Taste of Black Austin What : Greater Austin Black Chamber of Commerce’s inaugural Taste of Black Austin reception will explore the narrative of economic development through the historical context of food. More than a dozen chefs will prepare savory hors d’oeuvres inspired by African American dishes found in recipe books and menu selections archived by the Austin History Center and Black churches in the community. Where: Peached Social House, Brentwood Details : 6 to 9 p.m. $65. Community sponsor is $125 and include a VIP cooking demonstration preceding the reception. Tickets here . A portion of the proceeds will benefit Urban Roots. February 2017 Sunday, February 12 Jo's 11th Annual Chili Cook-Off What: Since 2005, Jo’s has hosted an annual Chili Cook-Off , Two Steppin’ Competition and Benefit each winter. The event supports non-profit groups addressing hunger issues locally and draws amateur and professional culinary talent into fierce battle for the prized trophy chili pot and cases of Shiner beer. Music by Jeff Hughes & Chaparral and The Jo’s House Band. Where : Hotel San Jose parking lot, South Congress Avenue Details : Noon to 3 p.m. Entry is free. Chili tasting wristbands are $20—you get a sample of each chili along with one ticket to vote for your favorite. Register to participate in the contest here . Thursday, February 16 Thinkery21: Fermentology What: Austin children's museum Thinkery hosts boozy over-21 nights; the next is on centered on all things fermented. Sip and sample your way through Austin’s best booze, brews and fermented foods (beer, cheese, and more) and and dig deep into what’s really going on at the molecular level in your favorite fermentables. Plus there will be catapult beer pong. Details : 7 p.m. $36 for members. $40 for nonmembers. Tickets here . March 2017 Friday, March 10 to Sunday, March 19 South By Southwest Rachael Ray has signed on to as one of the keynote speakers at SXSW to discuss her experiences at the intersection of food, entertainment, and music. Browse the confirmed sessions for the food track on the SXSW schedule here . Saturday, March 25 Tater Tots and Beer Festival What: It's tots on tots on tots with beer at the Tater Tots and Beer Festival . Guests can enjoy both the beer and tots while listening to live music in the Palm Park space. Where: Palm Park , 711 East 3rd Street Details: 3 to 6 p.m. Must be 21 years of age to attend. Both $33 general admission and $75 VIP tickets can be purchased here . There is limited space and tickets are expected to sell out, so purchase yours in advance. APRIL 2017 Sunday, April 2 2017 Texas Wine Revolution What: Texas Wine Revolution is returning for another wine-filled event to showcase more than 25 Texas wineries. Look for 100% Texas-grown Rosé. Where: Featherstone Ranch, 870 Klein Road, Stonewall What : 1 to 4 p.m. $33 per ticket if purchased before December 31. Price increases after that. Tickets here . Admission includes tasting of more than 25 Texas-grown Rosés, a six-bottle tote bag, a souvenir wine glass, entertainment, and food samples. Past Events
